newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP is biggest insider trading case - watchdog.
newsitem.headline: SAP is biggest insider trading case - watchdog.

text.p: The German securities watchdog said late on Thursday that between five and 10 cases of insider trading in the shares of German software group SAP were proveable.
Georg Dreyling, vice president of the BAWe supervisory body, told reporters that the BAWe planned further inquiries into the dealings of SAP staff members due to alleged insider trading.
Dreyling added that the SAP case is the biggest in Germany since such activity was criminalised in 1994.
"Objectively, between five and 10 primary SAP insiders certainly engaged in insider trading," Dreyling said.

Frankfurt prosecutors have launched an investigation to establish whether insider information was used to trade SAP shares and derivatives by more than 100 people around the time of the firm's third quarter results announcement on October 22 last year.

On Thursday, the prosecutors said that the probe had produced no evidence of wrongdoing among 71 SAP staff who had access to the results information ahead of time. They said investigations were now centred on four employees who had more limited access to information.
After the October results announcement, which came in well below market expectations, SAP shares plunged 23 percent.
